section-block.rac_essential-question: How can we help animals stay healthy?

section-block.rac_book_caption: Book: Clifford the Big Red Dog

section-block.rac_book_summary: This story introduces Clifford, the big red dog. Clifford’s enormous size has its benefits, and even though he has some bad habits, Emily Elizabeth would never trade him for a different pet!

section-block.rac_body-text: Point out several objects that are different sizes. Ask children to name a big object and a small object in the classroom.
Sing “The Wheels on the Bus” as “The Animals in the House,” filling in animals and sounds they make. For example: The cats in the house go purr purr purr...all through the day.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Clifford the Big Red Dog by Norman Bridwell.
Lala loves all sorts of books. She loves to look for math in narrative books like this one!
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read.
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What are some good things about having a dog?

section.rac_body-text: Focus on Counting: As you read, have children listen for size words such as tall, small, short, or large.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do you notice about Clifford? How is he different than other dogs?
The house is tall and so is Clifford! There is a word we use to talk about how tall something is: height.
A lion is a big cat. But Clifford is even bigger than a lion! What are some other animals Clifford might be bigger than?
Many dogs dig up flowers and chew shoes. Clifford digs up entire trees and chews the giant shoe sign. How is that different than what other dogs do?
We know Clifford’s size can get him in trouble. But being big is good too! How is Clifford’s size good? (MB)
Did you remember and think about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What are some good things about having a dog?
section.rac_body-text: Ask children to Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share their responses to this question.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: You can play with a dog.
Dogs teach you how to take care of something.
Dogs give you lots of love.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about dogs as children watch.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Is it fun to have a dog because they like to play?
What can be hard about having a pet?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Take advantage of everyday occurrences to teach vocabulary terms related to measurement. Using more precise terms such as “tall” or “long” instead of “big” can help children understand basic amounts and sizes.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Reframe the Narrative

rac_body-text.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Sometimes a bad situation can be looked at in a new and positive way. For example, maybe one day you couldn’t reach the top of the climbing wall, but you climbed higher than you ever had before. You are able to describe your situation in a new way to feel good.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will think about ways Emily Elizabeth looks at her situation and sees the positive in Clifford the Big Red Dog by Norman Bridwell.
This narrative is a story about a girl who sees the good in her dog even when he gets in trouble. Clifford loves finding ways to see the positive, and we know he also loves Emily Elizabeth!

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread and talk about some parts of the story to use our reframing the narrative Mind Builder.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to have children answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Clifford is so big that sometimes things can be hard. But what is good about him being big? (MB)
What would be hard about playing hide-and-seek with Clifford? What would be fun? (MB)
How is Clifford’s house a problem? Is it bigger or smaller than Emily Elizabeth’s house?
What does Emily Elizabeth use to give Clifford a bath and comb him?
Why does she need a bigger way to wash and comb him?
Clifford didn’t win first prize. But Emily Elizabeth felt positive anyway. Why? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Have children draw a picture that represents Clifford doing an activity he is too big for. Encourage children to think about what might be funny or silly about Clifford being so big. If time allows, help children add captions to their images that describe whether Clifford is bigger or smaller than the item in the picture.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about taking care of dogs.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Reframing the narrative in order to empower or motivate oneself is an important skill in the emotional development of children. Adults can model for children how to see a situation in a new and positive way (i.e., “You’re not first in line, but you get to stand next to your friend!”) in order to help them internalize this behavior. (Hall, Kordich, Pearson, 2003)

section-block.rac_body-text: Teach children to subitize. Flash the one-dot Number Card for two seconds and ask, “How many dots?” Repeat with the two-dot Number Card.
Review counting to five with children by having children clap one time after you say “one,” two times as you say “two,” and so on. Ask children to call numbers as well.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book Clifford the Big Red Dog by Norman Bridwell.
Lala loves reading stories with different numbers and sizes like this one!
When you have a dog, you need to make sure it has everything it needs. As we read today, think about this question: How does Emily Elizabeth take care of Clifford even though he is so big?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book. Facilitate back-and-forth conversations with children to extend language.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: We already know that Clifford is a very big dog. He is also very heavy. What are some other heavy animals? Let’s read to find out what this heavy dog needs.
Emily Elizabeth can easily ride on Clifford’s back. She is light. What are some other light objects that Clifford could carry?
Emily Elizabeth’s shirt has buttons on it. Without counting, how many buttons do you see?
Many dogs chase cars. Clifford is able to pick up a car. Could a smaller dog pick up a car? Why or why not?
This is one way that Emily Elizabeth takes care of Clifford. How much do you think he eats and drinks in a day?
Did you listen and remember as we read today? How does Emily Elizabeth take care of Clifford, even though he is so big?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Have children Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share their responses to this question.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: She gives him food and water.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you draw and write together about different sizes of dogs.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How does Emily Elizabeth keep Clifford clean?
What are some other ways Emily Elizabeth could keep Clifford clean?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Once children are familiar with the one-to-one correspondence of numbers, they will be able to look at small groups of objects, and understand intuitively what, for example, “three” looks like without having to count one-two-three. Practicing this skill will increase a child’s confidence in counting to higher numbers as well as addition.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Discover Animals | Week 2: Caring for Pets

section-block.rac_body-text: Practice subitizing with children. Flash the one- to five-dot Number Cards for two seconds each and ask, “How many dots?”
Play a game with pet sounds. Go around the circle and ask each child to make the sound of a pet and have other children guess which pet they are.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read What Pets Need. It is an informational poster full of facts.
Lala loves looking at informational posters. They provide great information!
Clifford the Big Red Dog and What Pets Need both show children with pets. Let’s look for more connections between them!
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show Clifford the Big Red Dog cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question: How can we help animals stay healthy?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Caring for Pets
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the Teacher Text on the Big Chart, stopping to ask these questions. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to respond.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How does a safe home keep pets healthy? What is Clifford’s home like? Which is bigger, Clifford’s home or this cat’s home?
What do you think this bird eats? Why do pets need healthy food?
Is this dog enjoying its bath? Do you think all pets like baths?
Who can show other ways that pets can get exercise? How does it change if a pet is bigger than you, like Clifford?
Giving a pet what it needs can be a lot of work. Loving your pet helps make that work fun. Pets also need love from you to feel happy and safe. (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Call out what Emily Elizabeth has to do to take care of her pet, Clifford (feed, bathe, keep him safe, etc.) and have children act out each scenario in pairs, with one child pretending to be Clifford and the other pretending to be Emily Elizabeth.
Provide a writing prompt about keeping pets healthy and give feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Cognate awareness helps children acquire a second language. Research shows children benefit from explicit instruction about words that are cognates. In this lesson, you can point out that exercise and the Spanish word ejercicio are cognates. Animal and the Spanish animal are cognates as well.

section-block.rac_body-text: Look for opportunities for children to count aloud or subitize small numbers as they act out the parts of Clifford and Emily Elizabeth. For example, counting the number of treats to feed Clifford.
Invite children to act out different ways of taking care of a pet. Encourage them to describe what they are doing and why.
Review these words that will be helpful to the conversation.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact Clifford the Big Red Dog by Norman Bridwell.
Who remembers if this book tells us a story or teaches us information?
We have learned about pets and how to take care of them. When we read today I want you to think about this question: How would you take care of a pet?
Let’s reread the book one more time together, this time with friends acting out the parts of Emily Elizabeth and Clifford.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to choose children to act out each part.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Emily Elizabeth and Clifford have fun together. She helps Clifford exercise by playing with him. What kinds of exercise do you do?
Emily Elizabeth says Clifford has some bad habits. He also has good habits. What are his good habits? Let’s act them out.
Let’s be Emily Elizabeth feeding Clifford. How many plates will we need to act this out? How many teapots?
What is Emily Elizabeth doing to take care of Clifford?
Emily Elizabeth does a lot to take care of Clifford. Why does she do all of that? How does Emily Elizabeth feel about Clifford?
Let’s talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How would you take care of a pet?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Then ask several children to share with the group.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I would walk my pet every day.
I would feed my pet food.
I would brush my pet’s fur.

section.rac_body-text: Ask children to draw or write about a pet they would like to have, its size, and how they would care for it, and share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What would you do to keep your pet healthy?
I would give my pet healthy f___ . (food)
I would give my pet healthy food.
What kind of pet would you like? How would that change how you take care of the pet?

section-block.rac_child_development_hed-green: Child Development: Try to Help Others
section-block.rac_child_development_body: Doing something for someone to try to make things better or easier is an important part of children’s social development. Discussing caring for pets and animals can help children develop these skills. Helping others can also include bringing an upset peer his or her favorite stuffed animal or blanket. (Denham and Burton, 2003)
